title-group.article-title: Herbivory-induced volatiles function as defenses increasing fitness of the native plant Nicotiana attenuata in nature

contrib-group.aff: Department of Molecular Ecology , Max Planck Institute for Chemical Ecology, Jena , Germany
Department of Molecular Ecology , Max Planck Institute for Developmental Biology, Tübingen , Germany

fn.p: Current address: Department of Biology and Ecology, Institute of Biological Sciences, Freiberg, Germany

license.license-p: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. This is an open-access article distributed under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution License, which permits unrestricted use, distribution, and reproduction in any medium, provided the original author and source are credited.

abstract.title: Textbook Summary
abstract.p: Furthermore, plants also produce so-called direct defenses which directly affect herbivores. Direct defenses may alter the effectiveness of indirect defense by affecting herbivore growth, resistance to attack, and palatability or toxicity to predators and parasitoids.

award-group.funding-source: Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation Marine Microbiology Initiative

funding-group.funding-statement: The funder(s) had no role in study design; collection, analysis, and interpretation of data; writing the article; and or the decision to submit to the journal.

ack.p: We thank S. Allmann for conducting egg predation assays in 2010; C. Diezel, M. Erb, M. Kallenbach, D. Kessler, D. Marciniak, M. Stanton, and A. Steppke for help with field work; S. Weigl for rating M. sexta damage levels; J. Gershenzon for the use of the HP GC-MS; M. Erb, J. Gershenzon, D. Heckel, M. Kallenbach, A. Kessler, A. Steppke, and A. Weinhold for comments on the manuscript; Brigham Young University for the use of their Lytle Preserve field station; and APHIS for constructive regulatory oversight.
